definition: Standardized ACR framework for characterizing and reporting imaging findings to improve communication between radiologists and clinicians.
Lung CT screening RADS system that standardizes reporting and management recommendations for lung cancer screening CT (versions v1.0, v1.1, v2022).
RSNA-controlled radiology terminology ontology (75,000+ terms) enabling interoperability and semantic parsing of radiology reports.
Standard system for naming and coding radiology procedures, harmonizing exam codes across practices.
Radiology report with logical, uniform structure built on checklists or knowledge trees, aimed at answering a clinical question and reducing diagnostic error.
Structured report tailored to the patient's clinical context to ensure it answers specific clinical questions efficiently.
Disease-specific structured questions guiding systematic imaging interpretation and structured report creation.
Software template (e.g., Lung-RADS Assistant) providing standardized structure and terminology to streamline reporting.
Disruptive problems in radiology reports often caused by cognitive biases and perceptual limits.
Critical findings that, if missed or ambiguously reported, delay care and affect major clinical decisions (e.g., admission or surgery).
Limitations in a radiologist's ability to visually perceive findings, contributing to diagnostic error.
Report errors involving dropped negations or incorrect left/right laterality, leading to misinterpretation.
Reporting guideline encouraging concise wording and avoidance of unnecessary words that do not add value.
Degree of agreement between radiologists when interpreting images; improved by structured and standardized reporting.
List of alternative diagnoses considered; radiology reports should usually limit this to three plausible options to avoid confusion.
Distinctive radiologic patterns that strongly suggest particular diagnoses and increase diagnostic confidence.
Contrast-enhanced CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis: nonenhancing thrombus centrally with enhancing triangular dural margins.
CT white cerebellum" pattern with diffuse low density of cerebral hemispheres and relatively high density of cerebellum/brainstem
T2-weighted MRI cruciform hyperintensity in the pons, typically associated with multisystem atrophy.
Biologic feature detectable on imaging; in radiomics, refers to computer-extracted quantitative imaging features linked to diagnosis or outcome.
Objective characteristic derived from in vivo images on a ratio or interval scale, indicating normal processes, disease, or response to therapy.
NLP process that extracts entities (e.g., disease names, anatomical sites) from free-text radiology reports for downstream analysis.
Clinical Text Analysis and Knowledge Extraction System; an NLP platform with dictionary-based NER for EMR free text.
Modified or core term of a compound term (e.g., effusion
column7: disease"); used to expand dictionary-based vocabularies."

definition: Multiword term with varied linguistic patterns that is difficult to capture using standard terminologies alone.
Compound Terms–Enhanced Dictionary created by adding missed compound terms and removing false positives to improve NER performance.
Metric describing frequency of stem terms in true positives or false negatives for dictionary-based NER.
Metric describing fraction of stem terms in false negatives that are matched by dictionaries (e.g., RadLex, SNOMED-CT).
Deep learning architecture used for image classification tasks such as lung nodule classification, extracting complex deep" features."
Families of texture-based radiomic features, including wavelet-based Gabor responses, extracted from intra- and perinodular regions to characterize heterogeneity.
Lung Image Database Consortium and Image Database Resource Initiative; public CT database with annotated lung nodules for CAD development and evaluation.
The Cancer Imaging Archive; de-identified cancer imaging repository (primarily DICOM) available for public download and research.
Low-dose computed tomography, typically noncontrast, used for lung cancer screening to reduce radiation exposure.
Focal lung lesion on CT, generally categorized as solid, part-solid, or pure ground-glass.
Pulmonary nodule size measured as mean of longest axial diameter and its perpendicular; growth defined as >2 mm (for <15 mm nodules) or >15 percent (for >15 mm nodules).
Dense nodule without any ground-glass component.
Hazy nodule with increased attenuation that does not obscure underlying bronchovascular structures.
Nodule containing both solid and nonsolid (ground-glass) components.
Nodule margin with irregular, radiating spikes" that increases the probability of malignancy."
Region inside the lung nodule from which radiomic texture features are extracted; strongly predictive of malignancy.
Parenchymal region immediately surrounding the nodule (e.g., within 5 mm) whose features improve classification when combined with intranodular features.
Most prevalent subtype of non-small cell lung cancer and most common true-positive finding in lung cancer screening.
Benign inflammatory lesion; most common confounding false positive in noncontrast lung cancer screening.
Solid, homogeneous nodule within approximately 15 mm of pleura or fissure, usually representing benign intrapulmonary lymph node.
Manual annotations that correctly match dictionary phrases in NER evaluation.
Dictionary phrases that match entities other than the manual annotations in NER evaluation.
Manual annotations not matched by dictionary phrases in NER evaluation.
NER performance metric: true_positives / (true_positives + false_positives) × 100.
NER performance metric: true_positives / (true_positives + false_negatives) × 100.
Harmonic mean of precision and recall: 2 × precision × recall / (precision + recall).
